title: Joshua Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 16.

questions.question: According to Joshua 16:4, which two groups took their inheritance?
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh and Ephraim
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:4 states that the children of Joseph, Manasseh and Ephraim, took their inheritance.

questions.question: What is the eastern border of the children of Ephraim according to Joshua 16:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Atarothaddar
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:5 says the eastern border was Atarothaddar unto Bethhoron the upper.

questions.question: Which city did the border pass by on the east according to Joshua 16:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Janohah
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:6 mentions the border passed by Janohah on the east.

questions.question: Where did the border go out from Tappuah according to Joshua 16:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Westward to the river Kanah
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:8 states the border went out from Tappuah westward unto the river Kanah.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 16:10 says the children of Ephraim fully drove out the Canaanites from Gezer.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 says they did not drive out the Canaanites that dwelt in Gezer; the Canaanites still dwelt there.

questions.question: According to Joshua 16:7, the border went out at which river?
questions.correctAnswer: Jordan
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:7 states the border came to Jericho and went out at Jordan.

questions.question: Which cities belonged to the children of Ephraim but were among the inheritance of Manasseh, as per Joshua 16:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Separate cities
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:9 says the separate cities for Ephraim were among the inheritance of Manasseh.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 16:1, the lot of the children of Joseph fell by the Jordan near Jericho.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:1 clearly states the lot of Joseph's children fell from Jordan by Jericho.

questions.question: From Bethel to which city did the border go out according to Joshua 16:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Luz
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:2 mentions the border goes out from Bethel to Luz.

questions.question: What sea did the border reach according to Joshua 16:3 and 16:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The sea
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:3 and 16:8 mention the border going out to the sea, without specifying a particular name.

questions.question: True or False: The Canaanites served under tribute to the Ephraimites according to Joshua 16:10.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 states that the Canaanites dwell among the Ephraimites and serve under tribute.

questions.question: According to Joshua 16:6, the border passed eastward to which place near Shiloh?
questions.correctAnswer: Taanathshiloh
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:6 describes the border going eastward unto Taanathshiloh.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Joshua 16:1: 'And the lot of the children of Joseph fell from Jordan by Jericho, unto the water of Jericho on the east, to the wilderness that goeth up from Jericho throughout _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: mount Bethel
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:1 states the wilderness goes up from Jericho throughout mount Bethel.

questions.question: According to Joshua 16:5, the border on the east side went from Atarothaddar to which place?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethhoron the upper
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:5 describes the border from Atarothaddar unto Bethhoron the upper on the east side.

questions.question: What did the border go down to from Janohah according to Joshua 16:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Ataroth and Naarath
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:7 says the border went down from Janohah to Ataroth and to Naarath.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with trust and obedience regarding God’s promises for their life. Based on Joshua 16:4, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: God’s promises will be fulfilled when we obey and trust Him
God’s promises depend on our works alone
Faith is not important in receiving God’s inheritance
Inheritance is only physical and not spiritual
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promises will be fulfilled when we obey and trust Him
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:4 shows that the children of Joseph, Manasseh and Ephraim, took their inheritance as God promised. This teaches us that faith and obedience lead to receiving God’s blessings. Verses 1-3 and 5-8 also emphasize the borders given by God, showing His faithfulness to provide.

questions.question: How does Joshua 16:10 teach us about dealing with unresolved challenges in our spiritual walk?
options: Sometimes challenges persist, and God calls us to persevere in faith
We should give up when difficulties arise
Ignoring problems is the best way to handle them
Only physical battles matter, not spiritual ones
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes challenges persist, and God calls us to persevere in faith
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 mentions that the Ephraimites did not drive out the Canaanites who dwelt among them but served under tribute. This illustrates that challenges and incomplete obedience can remain, requiring perseverance and faith. Verses 9 and 10 together show partial success but ongoing struggles.

questions.question: A believer is uncertain about their spiritual inheritance. According to Joshua 16:5-8, what principle about God’s provision can encourage them?
options: God provides an inheritance according to His plan and faithfulness
Inheritance is earned by human effort alone
God’s provision is random and unpredictable
questions.correctAnswer: God provides an inheritance according to His plan and faithfulness
questions.explanation: These verses detail the borders of Ephraim’s inheritance, showing God’s precise and faithful provision. This teaches us to trust God’s plan and timing for our spiritual blessings. Verses 1-4 and 6-8 highlight God’s sovereignty in allotting inheritance.

questions.question: How does the description of the land borders in Joshua 16:1-3 remind us to be diligent and precise in our spiritual walk?
options: Spiritual boundaries and disciplines require care and attention
God does not care about boundaries
Precision is only important in worldly matters
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual boundaries and disciplines require care and attention
questions.explanation: The careful description of the borders from Jordan by Jericho to the sea in verses 1-3 teaches the importance of knowing and respecting God’s spiritual boundaries. This parallels the need for diligence in prayer, obedience, and holiness. Verses 1-3 illustrate careful allotment and order.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with integrity at work. How would you apply the lesson from Joshua 16:9 about living honestly among others?
options: Live transparently and serve faithfully even when surrounded by others who may not share your values
Compromise to fit in with others
Integrity is optional when others are dishonest
Avoid working with people who are different
questions.correctAnswer: Live transparently and serve faithfully even when surrounded by others who may not share your values
questions.explanation: Verse 9 shows that Ephraim’s cities were among Manasseh’s inheritance, indicating coexistence and serving together with others. This teaches us to maintain integrity and faithfulness in diverse environments. Verses 9-10 support living honorably despite challenges.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 16 teaches that God’s promises of inheritance are unconditional and do not require obedience or faith.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter shows that the children of Joseph took their inheritance following God’s allotment and borders (verses 4, 5-8), implying obedience and trust in God’s Word are necessary to receive His promises. The presence of Canaanites among them (verse 10) also indicates incomplete obedience.

questions.question: What spiritual lesson can we learn about contentment from Joshua 16:8, where the border went out to the river Kanah and the sea?
options: Be content with the portion God assigns you, trusting His wisdom
Always seek to enlarge your territory by any means
Discontentment is a sign of spiritual maturity
God’s blessings are only for the most ambitious
questions.correctAnswer: Be content with the portion God assigns you, trusting His wisdom
questions.explanation: The clear definition of the border in verse 8 shows God’s sovereign provision. This teaches believers to trust and be content with what God provides, avoiding envy or greed. Verses 5-8 emphasize God’s ordered distribution.

questions.question: How does Joshua 16:7 encourage believers to persevere through trials when facing spiritual battles?
options: The border passes through difficult places but ultimately reaches God’s appointed limit
Trials mean God has abandoned us
Spiritual battles should be avoided at all costs
Perseverance is only for the strong
questions.correctAnswer: The border passes through difficult places but ultimately reaches God’s appointed limit
questions.explanation: Verse 7 describes the border going down through several places to the Jordan, showing a path with obstacles but a clear endpoint. This encourages perseverance through difficulties, trusting God’s appointed boundaries and timing. Verses 6-7 illustrate this journey.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 16 indicates that believers should expect complete victory and removal of all obstacles in their walk with God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 reveals that the Ephraimites did not drive out all the Canaanites, and they dwelt among them serving under tribute. This teaches that believers may face ongoing challenges and incomplete victories, requiring patience and faithfulness. Verses 9-10 illustrate this reality.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation in their family. How might Joshua 16:4-5 guide your counsel about trusting God’s provision in relationships?
options: Trust God’s plan for your family inheritance and seek harmony in His boundaries
Family struggles mean God has rejected you
You must control every family situation by your own power
God’s provision is limited to personal success, not family
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s plan for your family inheritance and seek harmony in His boundaries
questions.explanation: The passage details the inheritance given to Ephraim and Manasseh, showing God’s care for family provision and order. This encourages trust in God’s plan for family unity and reconciliation. Verses 4-5 emphasize God’s faithful allotment.

questions.question: How does the passage in Joshua 16:1-3 encourage believers in personal devotion and prayer discipline?
options: Just as the land’s borders are carefully defined, so should our prayer life be consistent and focused
Prayer is optional for spiritual growth
Devotion should be spontaneous without structure
Borders in scripture do not relate to personal discipline
questions.correctAnswer: Just as the land’s borders are carefully defined, so should our prayer life be consistent and focused
questions.explanation: The specific and detailed description of borders in verses 1-3 symbolizes the need for spiritual discipline and order in our devotion. Consistency in prayer and obedience parallels the careful allotment God made. Verses 1-3 highlight God’s order.

questions.question: A believer is called to serve in their church community. How does Joshua 16:9 suggest an attitude for serving alongside others?
options: Serve faithfully even when your inheritance overlaps with others, fostering unity
Only serve when given a special place
Serve only when you are recognized
questions.correctAnswer: Serve faithfully even when your inheritance overlaps with others, fostering unity
questions.explanation: Verse 9 indicates that Ephraim’s cities were among Manasseh’s inheritance, showing coexistence and shared spaces. This encourages believers to serve with humility and unity in the church, even when roles or blessings overlap. Verses 8-9 support this.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Joshua 16:6, the border went about eastward unto __________, and passed by it on the east.
questions.correctAnswer: Taanathshiloh
questions.explanation: Verse 6 specifically states the border went about eastward unto Taanathshiloh and passed by it on the east, showing the precise nature of God’s allotment.

questions.question: What does Joshua 16:10 teach about humility and living alongside those who differ from us in belief or practice?
options: Sometimes we must coexist humbly and show love even when others differ
We should isolate ourselves from those different
Humility is not necessary in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes we must coexist humbly and show love even when others differ
questions.explanation: Verse 10 reveals that Canaanites dwelt among the Ephraimites and served under tribute, illustrating coexistence despite differences. This teaches humility, patience, and love in community. Verses 9-10 emphasize this reality.

questions.question: How can Joshua 16:1-2 inspire believers to trust God’s guidance when navigating life’s uncertainties?
options: God’s guidance is clear and faithful even when the path seems uncertain
We must rely solely on our own understanding
Uncertainty means God is not leading us
God’s plans are secret and unknowable
questions.correctAnswer: God’s guidance is clear and faithful even when the path seems uncertain
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 describe the borders from Jordan by Jericho to Bethel and Luz, showing God’s clear direction despite the wilderness terrain. This encourages believers to trust God’s guidance through life’s uncertainties. Verses 1-3 reinforce God’s faithfulness.

questions.question: How does the allotment of inheritance in Joshua 16 teach about gratitude for God’s provision in daily life?
options: Gratitude arises from recognizing that all we have is given by God’s sovereign choice
Gratitude is only for spiritual blessings, not material
We earn everything by our own efforts
God’s provision is irrelevant to our attitude
questions.correctAnswer: Gratitude arises from recognizing that all we have is given by God’s sovereign choice
questions.explanation: The chapter’s detailed allotment of land to Ephraim and Manasseh (verses 4-8) shows God’s sovereignty and grace in provision. This teaches believers to be grateful in all circumstances. Verses 1-8 highlight God’s generous giving.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 16.

questions.question: From which river did the lot of the children of Joseph fall according to Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Jordan
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:1 states that the lot of the children of Joseph fell from Jordan by Jericho.

questions.question: Which city marks the boundary from Bethel to Luz in the inheritance of Joseph's children?
questions.correctAnswer: Luz
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:2 states the border goes out from Bethel to Luz.

questions.question: What is the geographical significance of Gezer in Joshua 16?
options: It is the western boundary of the inheritance
It is a city not driven out of by Ephraimites
It is the location of the sea border
It marks the eastern extent of the inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: It is a city not driven out of by Ephraimites
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 notes that the Canaanites were not driven out of Gezer and still dwelt there.

questions.question: Which two tribes are explicitly mentioned as taking their inheritance in Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh and Ephraim
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:4 specifies that the children of Joseph, Manasseh and Ephraim, took their inheritance.

questions.question: The border of the children of Ephraim included which eastern city according to Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Atarothaddar
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:5 states the east side border was Atarothaddar unto Bethhoron the upper.

questions.question: Joshua 16 describes the border going from Janohah to which two locations?
questions.correctAnswer: Ataroth and Naarath
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:7 says the border went down from Janohah to Ataroth and Naarath.

questions.question: Which river marked the western boundary of the tribe of Ephraim's inheritance?
questions.correctAnswer: Kanah
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:8 identifies the river Kanah as the western boundary going out to the sea.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Ephraim completely drove out the Canaanites from all their cities.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 states the Canaanites dwelling in Gezer were not driven out and served under tribute.

questions.question: How does the presence of Canaanites among Ephraimites in Gezer foreshadow later biblical themes?
options: It prefigures ongoing spiritual compromise and assimilation
It shows total conquest and purity of Israelite worship
It reflects a historical error in the text
It symbolizes complete separation of peoples
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures ongoing spiritual compromise and assimilation
questions.explanation: The coexistence of Canaanites among Ephraimites (Joshua 16:10) anticipates later biblical warnings against idolatry and assimilation.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the detailed description of boundaries in Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Geographical enumeration
questions.explanation: Joshua 16 uses detailed geographical enumeration to establish tribal boundaries as a historical and theological claim.

questions.question: Which city is mentioned as being 'on the east' side of the border near Bethel?
questions.correctAnswer: Taanathshiloh
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:6 describes the border going eastward unto Taanathshiloh and passing it on the east side.

questions.question: How does Joshua 16's account of inheritance relate to the broader theme of God's promise to Abraham?
options: It shows the fulfillment of God's land promise to Abraham's descendants
It contradicts the promise by dividing the land unfairly
It focuses only on military conquest without reference to promise
It ignores the tribe of Joseph completely
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the fulfillment of God's land promise to Abraham's descendants
questions.explanation: The allotment of land to Joseph's children (Joshua 16:4) reflects the fulfillment of God's covenant with Abraham regarding land inheritance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'unto the sea' repeated in the chapter?
options: It emphasizes the western boundary reaching the Mediterranean Sea
It indicates a spiritual boundary rather than physical
It is a reference to the Red Sea
It denotes a symbolic boundary of purity
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the western boundary reaching the Mediterranean Sea
questions.explanation: The repeated mention of 'unto the sea' (Joshua 16:3, 16:8) refers explicitly to the western boundary reaching the Mediterranean Sea.

questions.question: Which cultural context is critical for understanding the significance of the Israelites not driving out the Canaanites from Gezer?
options: Ancient Near Eastern conquest practices and assimilation threats
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern conquest practices and assimilation threats
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 reflects the cultural context of conquest and the dangers of foreign peoples remaining among Israel, posing spiritual and cultural challenges.

questions.question: What does the mention of 'separate cities for the children of Ephraim among the inheritance of Manasseh' imply about tribal relations?
options: It suggests overlapping tribal territories and complex land allotments
It indicates complete separation of tribes
It shows Ephraim conquered Manasseh's land
It means Manasseh had no land inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests overlapping tribal territories and complex land allotments
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:9 notes that Ephraim's cities were among Manasseh's inheritance, indicating non-contiguous boundaries and complex tribal relations.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What significant theological theme can be drawn from the division of land among the children of Joseph in Joshua 16?
options: God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises to Israel
The failure of Israel to obey God's commands
The universality of the gospel message
The final judgment of God upon the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises to Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:1-4 describes the inheritance given to Joseph’s descendants, demonstrating God's faithfulness in fulfilling the promise to Abraham (Genesis 15:18-21; Exodus 23:31; Deuteronomy 1:8; Acts 7:5). This typifies God’s faithfulness throughout Scripture.

questions.question: Which tribes received the inheritance described in Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh and Ephraim
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:4 clearly states that the children of Joseph, specifically Manasseh and Ephraim, took their inheritance. This highlights the tribal divisions and God's orderly allotment of land (Numbers 26:28-37; Deuteronomy 33:17; 1 Chronicles 7:14-20).

questions.question: What does the presence of Canaanites dwelling among the Ephraimites in Gezer suggest about Israel’s obedience and God’s judgment?
options: Partial obedience resulted in ongoing subjugation and tribute
Complete victory and possession of the land
God’s immediate removal of all enemies
The end of Canaanite influence in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Partial obedience resulted in ongoing subjugation and tribute
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 explains that the Ephraimites did not drive out the Canaanites fully, resulting in them dwelling among Israel and serving under tribute. This illustrates the consequences of incomplete obedience (Judges 1:27-36; Exodus 23:31-33; Numbers 33:55; 1 Kings 9:20-21).

questions.question: Which city marked the eastern boundary of the inheritance of the children of Joseph according to Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Jericho
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:1 and 16:7 mention Jericho as a boundary point on the east, emphasizing it as a key landmark in the inheritance. This is consistent with Jericho's historical and theological significance (Deuteronomy 34:3; Joshua 6:1; Hebrews 11:30; 2 Samuel 10:5).

questions.question: The inheritance boundaries of Ephraim included a border going out toward which sea?
questions.correctAnswer: The Mediterranean Sea
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:3, 16:6, and 16:8 indicate the boundary extending to the sea, which is understood as the Mediterranean Sea, the western border of Israel. This points to God's providential establishment of Israel’s borders (Psalm 24:2; Isaiah 11:15; Ezekiel 47:10; Acts 27:41).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about God’s sovereignty is illustrated by the lot determining the land inheritance in Joshua 16?
options: God’s sovereign control over the distribution of blessings
Human free will exclusively determines inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign control over the distribution of blessings
questions.explanation: The lot casting for land (Joshua 16:1) reflects divine sovereignty in allotting blessings and calling, which aligns with biblical teaching on God’s providence (Proverbs 16:33; Psalm 16:6; Acts 1:26; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: How does Joshua 16 demonstrate the principle of covenant faithfulness in the Old Testament?
options: By showing God fulfilling land promises to Jacob’s descendants
By focusing on temple worship alone
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God fulfilling land promises to Jacob’s descendants
questions.explanation: The allotment to Joseph’s sons in Joshua 16 shows God’s covenant faithfulness to the patriarchs (Genesis 28:13-15; Exodus 23:20-33; Deuteronomy 7:12-15; Joshua 21:43-45).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh as indicated in Joshua 16?
options: They were closely connected yet had distinct inheritances
They merged into a single tribe with no distinction
They lived entirely separate without any shared cities
questions.correctAnswer: They were closely connected yet had distinct inheritances
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:9 notes that Ephraim’s cities were among Manasseh’s inheritance, showing their close relationship as Joseph’s sons but distinct tribal boundaries (Genesis 48:5-6; Numbers 1:32-35; 1 Chronicles 7:14-20; Joshua 17:1-6).

questions.question: Which theological lesson about human responsibility and divine discipline can be inferred from the Ephraimites’ failure to drive out the Canaanites?
options: Partial obedience leads to ongoing spiritual and social compromise
God always removes enemies regardless of obedience
Obedience is irrelevant to God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: Partial obedience leads to ongoing spiritual and social compromise
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:10 shows that failing to fully obey God’s command resulted in the Israelites living with Canaanites who became tributaries. This aligns with themes in Judges 2:1-3, 1 Kings 9:20-21, and Exodus 23:31-33 about consequences of incomplete obedience.

questions.question: What is the significance of the detailed boundary descriptions in Joshua 16 for biblical ecclesiology?
options: They emphasize God’s order and holiness in community life
They indicate God’s indifference to land and people
They focus only on political power
They reject tribal distinctions in the church
questions.correctAnswer: They emphasize God’s order and holiness in community life
questions.explanation: The precise boundaries (Joshua 16:2-8) reveal God’s concern for order, holiness, and identity within His people, foundational principles reflected in the New Testament church’s structure (1 Corinthians 12:12-27; Ephesians 4:11-16; Hebrews 12:14; Revelation 21:27).

questions.question: Which Old Testament promise is fulfilled through the land inheritance described in Joshua 16?
options: The promise to Abraham of a land for his descendants
The promise of a Messiah from Judah
The promise of a restored temple
The promise of the New Covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The promise to Abraham of a land for his descendants
questions.explanation: The land allotment to Joseph’s descendants fulfills God’s promise to Abraham in Genesis 12:7 and 15:18-21, which is a key theme in biblical theology (Exodus 6:8; Deuteronomy 1:8; Acts 7:5).

questions.question: How does the inheritance of the children of Joseph in Joshua 16 relate to Christological themes?
options: Joseph’s blessings prefigure Christ’s spiritual inheritance
It predicts Christ’s rejection by Israel only
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph’s blessings prefigure Christ’s spiritual inheritance
questions.explanation: Joseph’s inheritance (Joshua 16:4) is often seen typologically as prefiguring Christ, the ultimate inheritor of God’s promises and the source of spiritual blessing (Hebrews 7:14; Romans 8:17; Ephesians 1:11; Revelation 5:9-10).

questions.question: What does the mention of cities and villages in Joshua 16:9 imply about God’s provision for His people?
options: God provides both urban and rural means for community sustenance
questions.correctAnswer: God provides both urban and rural means for community sustenance
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:9’s reference to cities and villages shows God’s comprehensive provision for Israel’s social and economic life, consistent with biblical concern for community (Deuteronomy 20:5-8; Nehemiah 11:1-2; Psalm 107:7; Acts 2:46).

questions.question: What eschatological hope is foreshadowed by the inheritance of the land to the tribes in Joshua 16?
options: The promised eternal rest and inheritance for God’s people
The end of the world at Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The promised eternal rest and inheritance for God’s people
questions.explanation: The land inheritance symbolizes God’s promise of rest and an eternal inheritance (Psalm 95:11; Hebrews 4:8-11; Revelation 21:1-4; Romans 8:17), pointing beyond the physical land to the spiritual rest in Christ.

questions.question: Which of these places is NOT mentioned as a boundary marker in Joshua 16?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethlehem
questions.explanation: Joshua 16:2-7 lists Ataroth, Luz, and Janohah as boundary markers, but Bethlehem is not mentioned in this chapter’s boundaries. This highlights the careful delineation of tribal lands (Joshua 15:1-12; Judges 1:21; 1 Samuel 17:12).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'serve under tribute' in Joshua 16:10 teach about sin and its consequences?
options: Sin leads to subjugation and loss of full blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to subjugation and loss of full blessing
questions.explanation: The Canaanites serving under tribute (Joshua 16:10) illustrate how disobedience results in loss of full blessing and ongoing hardship, consistent with biblical teaching on sin’s consequences (Genesis 3:16-19; Romans 6:23; Hebrews 12:5-11; Galatians 6:7-8).
